item.title: Israel and World Grapple With Sharon’s Mixed Legacy
item.description: A life and career paralleled Israel’s development, for better or worse.
item.dc:creator: By RINA CASTELNUOVO and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Presidential Run Likely for Egypt’s Top General
item.description: The officer, General Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, all but explicitly linked his candidacy to this week’s referendum on a revised constitution, in an apparent bid to exploit his personal popularity to boost the margin of victory for that vote.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Defying Japan, Rancher Saves Fukushima’s Radioactive Cows
item.description: Angered by what he considers Japan’s efforts to sweep away the inconvenient truths of a nuclear disaster, a rancher returns to the no-man’s land near the devastated plant.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times

item.title: A Guillotine in Storage Bears Signs of a Role in Silencing Nazis’ Critics
item.description: The Bavarian National Museum has provisionally identified a guillotine as the one the Nazis used to execute Sophie and Hans Scholl, who led the White Rose resistance to Hitler.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: ADN/Picture-Alliance, via DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Hans and Sophie Scholl were executed in 1943 for leading a student resistance against the Nazis.

item.title: Total of France Is Expected to Seek Shale Gas in Britain
item.description: It would be the first major oil company explore for natural gas and oil in shale rock in that country.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED

item.title: Ariel Sharon, 1928-2014
item.description: A cunning general who went on to hold nearly every top Israeli government post, Mr. Sharon suffered a stroke in 2006 and fell into a coma from which he never awoke.

item.title: Ariel Sharon, Fierce Defender of a Strong Israel, Dies at 85
item.description: Mr. Sharon was both vilified and admired for his belief that Jews must assert and defend their collective needs without embarrassment or fear of censure.
item.dc:creator: By ETHAN BRONNER
item.media:description: Mr. Sharon met with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt at the Movenpick Golf Resort in Sharm El-Sheikh in 2005.

item.title: Seven Injured in Thai Protest Shooting, Capital Beefs Up Security
item.description: Gunmen opened fire on anti-government protesters in Bangkok early Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Fire Ravages China District Said to Inspire Shangri-La
item.description: The fire broke out in Dukezong in Yunnan Province, which has cast itself as an inspiration for the mythic Shangri-la.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Firefighters tried to fortify a wooden building as fire ravaged the ancient town of Dukezong in Yunnan Province.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: New Clashes Erupt in Ukraine After Trial
item.description: At least a dozen protesters were injured in clashes with riot police after a Ukrainian court on Friday convicted three men of plotting to topple a statue of Vladimir Lenin in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Sudan: Army Says Its Soldiers Have Regained Control of Northern City
item.description: South Sudan’s military on Friday retook Bentiu, the capital of an oil-producing state, from rebels loyal to the former vice president, according to a military spokesman.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Wrecked Ship to Be Towed in June
item.description: The cruise ship Costa Concordia will be lifted off the seabed by 30 huge tanks filled with air so it can be towed away from the Italian island where it capsized two years ago.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria to Release 167 Detainees
item.description: Nigeria’s Ministry of Defense said President Goodluck Jonathan has ordered the release of 167 people who were arrested during a military campaign to end an Islamist insurgency in the northeast.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Suspects in Bombing Arrested
item.description: A Russian committee said Friday that it had detained six men suspected in a bombing in the southern city of Pyatigorsk last month that killed three people.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Airstrike Hits Militants’ Camp in Somalia
item.description: The Kenyan military said Friday that it had killed at least 30 Islamic militants in an airstrike on one of their camps in Somalia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Advisers Sent to Help Somalia Fight the Shabab
item.description: Three military advisers were deployed to Somalia last month to help provide logistics, planning and communication assistance to forces combating the Islamic militant group.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Bank Is Criticized for Honduran Loan
item.description: The bank’s ombudsman delivered a stinging review of a loan to a palm-oil company engaged in a violent conflict with poor farm workers over land in Honduras.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Wojciech Kilar, 81, Polish Composer for Film, Dies
item.description: Mr. Kilar won recognition for his music for “The Pianist” and “Bram Stoker’s Dracula” as well as works inspired by Polish folk music.
item.category: American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Wojciech Kilar in September. He wrote music for films including “The Pianist” and “Bram Stoker’s Dracula.”

item.title: U.S. Says Iran Won’t Attend Peace Talks on Syria
item.description: American officials say Iran has made no effort to use its influence to get the Syrian government to cease bombing and allow humanitarian aid.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: As Indian Diplomat Exits After Arrest, a Culture Clash Lingers
item.description: Devyani Khobragade’s return to India represented a possible resolution of a case that has harmed the United States’ ties with New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, and her father, Uttam Khobragade, left, were escorted on Friday at a state guesthouse in New Delhi.

item.title: Nelson Ned, Florid Brazilian Balladeer, Dies at 66
item.description: Mr. Ned’s records and his sentimental style brought him a large following throughout Latin America.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: The Lede: Fury in Sri Lanka at U.S. Embassy Tweet on Killing of Tamils
item.description: The Sri Lankan ministry of defense expressed shock and anger on Friday at what it called a “baseless allegation” against the nation’s military posted on the official Twitter feed of the U.S. Embassy in Colombo the day before.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Thai Beer Loses Esteem After Heiress’s Remarks
item.description: Voters in rural Thailand have begun boycotting the popular Singha beer brand because of its affiliation to the leader of antigovernment protests.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: People drank Chang beer at a bar in Udon Thani, Thailand, in January.

item.title: Crime Scene: In Rhino Horn Case, Judge Sees a Criminal Instead of a ‘Naïve Kid’
item.description: Michael Slattery Jr., who pleaded guilty last year to trafficking in the horns of an endangered species of rhinoceros, was sentenced to 14 months in prison.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WILSON
item.media:credit: US Attorney's Office - Eastern District of New York
item.media:description: Michael Slattery Jr. sold horns of endangered black rhinos.

item.title: Central African Leader’s Exit Sets Off Rejoicing in the Streets
item.description: Michel Djotodia, the Central African Republic’s president, quit under pressure after regional leaders held him responsible for failing to halt continuing sectarian violence in the country.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Demonstrators against Michel Djotodia’s rebel group, Seleka, held signs reading "Djotodia resign" as they marched to Mpoko Airport in Bangui, Central African Republic, on Friday.
